clinical_study.brief_title: Using Question Prompt Lists During Pediatric Asthma Visits to Increase Adolescent Involvement
clinical_study.official_title: Using Question Prompt Lists During Pediatric Asthma Visits to Increase Adolescent Involvement

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to conduct a randomized controlled trial with English and Spanish-speaking adolescents to compare the effectiveness of an adolescent "asthma question prompt list" with a supportive educational video intervention with usual care.
The hypothesis of this study is that by showing the parents and adolescents the educational video and then providing the adolescents with the one-page "asthma question prompt lists" to use during their visits will improve: (a) asthma control, (b) adolescent self-efficacy in managing asthma, and (c) adolescent quality-of-life.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study uses a randomized controlled trial design stratified by provider to assess the impact of an adolescent "asthma question prompt list" combined with a supportive educational video emphasizing the importance of adolescent involvement and question-asking on communication during pediatric visits. This application is based on Social Cognitive Theory. Self-confidence or self-efficacy is a central component of Social Cognitive Theory (SCT) Application of Social Cognitive Theory (SCT) in asthma populations has shown that technical advice from providers is one external factor that can improve asthma management self-efficacy. Additionally, personal beliefs, such as outcome expectations, and family factors, such as parent and adolescent responsibility for asthma self-management, have been shown to affect adolescent self-efficacy and disease management outcomes. Prior work has found that adolescent self-efficacy in asthma management correlates strongly with health status, adherence, asthma medication device technique, asthma symptoms, and impact of illness on the family.
All adolescents will have their medical visits audio recorded. The adolescent will be interviewed after his/her medical visit while his/her caregiver/parent completes a survey at the time of study enrollment. This same procedure will be used when the adolescent and caregiver/parents return for the 6- and 12-month follow-up visits.

primary_outcome.description: This will be measured via the 5-item Asthma Control Test, responses are summed to indicate a score ranging from 5 (poor asthma control ) to 25 (complete asthma control).

secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as a continuous variable using a 14-item scale. Comparing adolescent asthma management self-efficacy between groups using the 12-month follow-up data

This will be measured as a continuous variable using a standardized version of the Juniper pediatric asthma quality-of-life questionnaire. The questionnaire will be administered as part of the adolescent interview and parent survey.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Questions the Adolescent Asks about Asthma or Its Treatment during the audio-tape visits.
secondary_outcome.description: This will be coded from the transcript of the audio-taped visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Providers include adolescent input into the asthma management plan.
secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as a dichotomous variable (yes/no). It occurs when the provider includes the adolescent's input about preferred treatment options when deciding on a treatment regimen. This data will be collected from the transcript of the audio-taped visit.
This will be measured by using the 12-item Child Satisfaction Questionnaire to measure provider-adolescent rapport and the adolescent's comfort with communication during the medical visit.
This will be measured in two ways, through parent report and pharmacy refill records.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of parent reported medicine problems
secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as a continuous variable with a range from zero to eight reported problems from the parent survey.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of adolescent reported medicine problems
secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as a continuous variable with a range from zero to seven reported problems from the adolescent survey.

secondary_outcome.measure: Emergency Department (ED) asthma visits during the past 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as the number of Emergency Department (ED) asthma visits during the past 12 months and will be extracted from the participant's medical record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Unscheduled physician visits during the past 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: This will be measured as the number of unscheduled physician visits made during the past 12 months and will be extracted from the participant's medical record.
The primary spirometry measurement of the Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second (FEV1) only will be extracted from the participant's medical record.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Educational Video and Question Prompt List
arm_group.description: Parents and adolescents in this group will watch a short educational video in English or Spanish on an iPad about the importance of encouraging adolescents to ask questions and to be involved during their pediatric asthma visits to improve their self-management skills. Also, the adolescents in this group will be handed a question prompt list to complete, which will be collected after the medical visit.
Standard of care will be used
